question: It is true that the ps command shows the list of running processes.
It is false that the ps command is used to stop running processes.

It is false that the wait command can terminate a process.

It is false that the sleep command can be used to stop a process immediately.
It is true that the exit command ends a script or process.
It is false that the exit command waits for a process to finish before ending.
It is true that the kill command stops a running process by its Process ID (PID).
It is false that the kill command pauses a process for a specific time.
It is true that the ps command shows the terminal associated with each process.
It is false that the ps command provides a list of only system processes.
It is true that the ps aux command displays all running processes on the system.
It is false that the ps aux command only shows processes associated with the current user.
It is true that the $! variable stores the Process ID of the last background command.
It is false that the $! variable is used to store the status code of a process.

It is false that the exit command is only used to terminate background processes.
It is true that the kill command can be used to forcefully terminate a process with the -9 option.
It is false that the kill command only works for foreground processes.

It is false that pkill only terminates a single instance of a process.

It is false that the wait command can be used to terminate a process after waiting.

It is false that the sleep command pauses execution indefinitely.
